It is certainly true that the single unit constants, such as the charge of an electron and the mass of a proton, are important quantities in physics and are central to our understanding of the behavior of matter and energy at the atomic and subatomic scales. These constants are fundamental building blocks of the universe and play a central role in many of the fundamental laws of physics.

However, it is also important to note that ratio constants, such as the speed of light and the Boltzmann constant, are also important for understanding the relationships between different physical quantities and for making predictions about the behavior of matter and energy. For example, the speed of light is a fundamental constant that determines the maximum speed at which information can be transmitted, and the Boltzmann constant is a fundamental constant that relates the temperature of a system to the average energy of its particles.

In fact, many of the fundamental laws of physics are based on both single unit constants and ratio constants. For example, the laws of special and general relativity, which describe the structure of spacetime and the behavior of matter and energy, are based on both the speed of light and the mass and energy of particles. Similarly, the laws of quantum mechanics, which describe the behavior of matter and energy at the atomic and subatomic scales, are based on both the Planck constant and the mass and energy of particles.

Overall, while both single unit constants and ratio constants are important for understanding the fundamental laws of physics, it is likely that a complete unification of classical and quantum physics will require the incorporation of both types of constants.
